TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Pachic Haplocryolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Razorba channery loam, native woodland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
0--1 inch to 0; litter of leaves, twigs, and bark in varying stages of decomposition.  (0 to 3 inches thick)
A1--0 to 9 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) channery sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable; about 20 percent fine channery fragments; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary.  (4 to 13 inches thick)
A2--9 to 20 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) channery sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable; about 30 percent fine channery fragments; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 30 inches thick)
A3--20 to 35 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) channery sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable; about 30 percent fine channery fragments; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary.  (3 to 15 inches thick)
C--35 to 60 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) channery sandy loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; massive; soft, very friable; about 25 percent fine channery fragments; strongly effervescent; moderately alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Rio Blanco County, Colorado; about 22 miles south of Rangely, on the east side of Texas Mountain, about 1,900 feet west and 1,900 feet south of the NE corner of Sec. 28, T. 3 S., R. 102 W.  U.S.S.S. Texas Mountain quad.; Lat. 39 degrees, 45 minutes, 38 seconds N., and Long. 108 degrees, 50 minutes, 42 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 39 to 43 degrees F., and the mean summer soil temperature is 54 to 59 degrees F.  The mollic epipedon is 16 to 40 inches thick.  The soil is usually moist and is not dry for as much as 90 cumulative days in some subhorizons of the moisture control section.  The particle-size control section is moderately coarse textured, and has 12 to 18 percent clay in the fine earth fraction.  Rock fragments range from 15 to 35 percent (by volume) and are mainly less than 3 inches in diameter.  The lower part of the control section has as much as 45 percent rock fragments in some pedons.   Depth to bedrock is more than 60 inches.
The A horizon has value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  Reaction is moderately alkaline.
The C horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  Reaction is moderately alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Aycab (NV), Cindersprings (ID), Coffeepot (NV), Coutis (WY), Earcree (ID), Foxvire (NV), Gardners Fork (UT), Hailman (UT), Moonlight (ID), Naz (ID), Shook (MT), Skyway (CO), Taral (AK), and Tosp (MT) series.  Ascab soils have a paralithic contact at 24 to 40 inches.  Cinderspring soils are leached of carbonates in the upper horizons and have rock fragments composed of cinders, and have cinders below 40 inches.  Coffeepot soils have a paralithic contact at 40 to 60 inches.  Coutis soils have less than 15 percent rock fragments and are slightly acid or neutral.  Earcree and Gardners Fork soils are noncalcareous and are neutral through moderately acid.  Foxvire soils lack carbonates throughout the profile.  Foxvire soils lack carbonates throughout the profile.  Hailman soils have a B2 horizon and a cobbly loam control section and are slightly acid or moderately acid.  Naz soils have 5 to 13 percent clay and contain less than 20 percent rock fragments.  Shook soils are noncalcareous in the upper horizons, have a Bw horizon, and have a high proportion of medium and coarse angular sand.  Moonlight soils have cambic horizons, lack carbonates throughout, and are moderately acid to neutral.  Skyway soils have a lithic contact at depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Taral soils lack carbonates throughout, have a subarctic continental climate with mean annual temperature of 23 to 27 degrees F.  Tosp soils lack carbonates throughout, are 40 to 60 inches deep over granitic bedrock, and average less than 15 percent rock fragments in the texture control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Razorba soils are on smooth to concave portions of mountain slopes which are significantly shaded from the sun.  They are at elevations between 7,000 and 8,400 feet.  Slope gradients are 30 to 75 percent.  Parent material is marlstone or calcareous fine grained sandstone or shale.  The average annual precipitation ranges from about 18 to 22 inches, of which about one-half falls during the spring and summer.  The average annual temperature ranges from 37 to 41 degrees F., and the frost-free season is less than 75 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Parachute and Rhone soils.  Parachute soils have a lithic contact at 20 to 40 inches and have more than 35 percent rock fragments.  Rhone soils have more than 18 percent clay and have less than 15 percent rock fragments in their solum.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used mainly for watershed purposes and as habitat for wildlife.  The principal vegetation is Douglas-fir, serviceberry, and snowberry.  Less steep or less north facing slopes also support pinyon.  Lesser components of understory include Oregon grape, American vetch, elk sedge, and mountain brome.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northwestern Colorado and possibly adjacent parts of Utah.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized are:  a mollic epipedon 16 to 40 inches thick; coarse loamy texture control section; an ustic moisture regime; and a cryic temperature regime.  Last updated by the state 4/95.
